perturbation.original_text:
Either party ("the Terminating Party") may terminate this Agreement upon prior written notice to the other party (the "Defaulting Party") upon the occurrence of any of the following conditions:

              (i) In the event that such party materially breaches this   Agreement or materially defaults in the performance of any obligation hereunder and fails to cure said breach within 30 days of written notice to the Defaulting Party by the Terminating Party;
perturbation.changed_text:
Either party ("the Terminating Party") may terminate this Agreement upon prior written notice to the other party (the "Defaulting Party") upon the occurrence of any of the following conditions:

              (i) In the event that such party materially breaches this   Agreement or materially defaults in the performance of any obligation hereunder and fails to cure said breach within 10 days of written notice to the Defaulting Party by the Terminating Party;
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach from 30 days to 10 days could be deemed unreasonable and conflict with general contract law principles regarding sufficient opportunity to remedy a breach, potentially rendering this clause unenforceable under Tennessee law, which prioritizes fair dealing and reasonable notice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Tennessee contract law - principles of reasonable notice and opportunity to cure a breach.

perturbation.original_text: SRP shall provide at its expense, and maintain throughout the term of this Agreement, comprehensive general liability insurance in the amount of Five Million Dollars and No/100's ($5,000,000.00) per occurrence with respect to any liability relating to the activities of SRP in the performance of this Agreement SRP shall supply Logan's with a copy of the Certificate of Insurance naming Logan's as an additional insured. Such policies shall provide for at least fifteen (15) days' written notice to Logan's of the cancellation or substantial modification thereof.
perturbation.changed_text: SRP shall provide at its expense, and maintain throughout the term of this Agreement, comprehensive general liability insurance in the amount of Five Million Dollars and No/100's ($5,000,000.00) per occurrence with respect to any liability relating to the activities of SRP in the performance of this Agreement SRP shall supply Logan's with a copy of the Certificate of Insurance naming Logan's as an additional insured. Such policies shall provide for at least five (5) days' written notice to Logan's of the cancellation or substantial modification thereof.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for insurance cancellation or modification from 15 days to 5 days creates an inconsistency. Standard insurance practices and some state regulations (though not explicitly defined in Tennessee statutes regarding general liability policies for sponsorships) often require insurers to provide a minimum of 10-30 days' notice to additional insured parties for policy changes or cancellations, allowing adequate time to secure alternative coverage, which this modification does not satisfy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General insurance industry standards and best practices for notification of policy changes/cancellations, potentially creating a legal challenge based on 'reasonableness'.

perturbation.original_text: In the event Logan's terminates this Agreement pursuant to this Article 10, Logan's shall be entitled to a pro rata refund of amounts prepaid for the current calendar year, with no further obligations under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event Logan's terminates this Agreement pursuant to this Article 10, Logan's is entitled to no refund amounts prepaid for the current calendar year, and has no further obligations under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the pro rata refund, the contract now stipulates that Logan's keeps all prepaid amounts even if they terminate the agreement. This may be viewed as an unreasonable penalty or unjust enrichment under Tennessee law, especially if the termination occurs early in the calendar year and is not due to SRP's fault. This clause could be challenged as unconscionable or a violation of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Tennessee contract law regarding unjust enrichment, unconscionability, and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
